Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Multiple Conferences to be held at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory in 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support attendance by early-career and minority scientists to seven conferences to be held in 2016 at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, including: Systems Biology: Global Regulation of Gene Expression; Evolutionary Biology of Caenorhabditis & Other Nematodes; Nuclear Organization & Function; Regulatory & Non-Coding RNAs; Translational Control; Epigenetics & Chromatin; Germ Cells; and Biological Data Science. Each conference will include presentations by junior and senior investigators in a format designed to promote scientific exchange in formal and informal settings. Results from the conferences will be disseminated via distribution of abstract books and via the CSHL Leading Strand video archive.

Each conference will address a variety of up-to-date, cutting edge topics relevant to each field of research, with emphasis on fostering cross-disciplinary and forward-looking discussions and collaborations.

Co-funded by the following programs in the Directorate of Biological Sciences: Genetic Mechanisms and Cellular Dynamics and Function in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience; Developmental Systems in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems; and Advances in Biological Informatics in the Division of Biological Infrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported young scientists to attend one of eight Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory (CSHL) meetings in 2016. The funds supported graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, junior principal investigators, and scientists at all career levels from underrepresented minority (URM) groups who actively participated in one of the meetings by submitting an abstract and presenting either a poster or talk. Individual scholarships were awarded based on several factors including financial need outlined in written scholarship requests, geographic distance from CSHL, race/ethnicity, and other support available to a participant. Preference was given to scientists from U.S. laboratories.

Attendees at the following eight 2016 meetings were eligible for scholarship funds through this project: Systems Biology (Global Regulation of Gene Expression), Evolutionary Biology of Caenorhabditis & Other Nematodes, Nuclear Organization & Function, Regulatory & Non-Coding RNAs, Translational Control, Epigenetics & Chromatin, Germ Cells, and Biological Data Science. All eight meetings featured discussion topics that align well with NSF BIO’s research funding priorities, especially those regarding basic (non-biomedical) research, interdisciplinarity, and the integration of laboratory-based approaches with quantitative modeling. The eight meetings also featured significant components designed to facilitate the active participation of younger scientists.

In total, financial aid was provided to assist 103 young scientists in attending one of the eight meetings, all of whom were U.S. attendees and 13% of whom self-identified as being from a URM population (Black/African American, Hispanic/Latino, American Indian/Alaska Native, or Native Hawaiian/Other Pacific Islander). The vast majority of aid recipients were either students or postdoctoral scholars (91%), with the remaining recipients being young principal investigators.
